ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This was my first philosophy class, so I learned a lot about philosophical approaches/terms/ideas, in additional to (obviously) a ton of religious philosophy.
philosophy of religion

learned about all of the big philosophical questions of religion (think both atheistic and theistic responses to questions like Does God exist? Why or why not? How could there be a good God in a world with so much suffering? Why is God hidden, if he does exist? If God exists, do we have free will? What place does rational/critical thinking have in religion? To what extent does science confirm or disconfirm the existence of God? AND SO MUCH MORE.). 

Learned how to write a philosophy essay, got to read philosophy for the first time, and have cool seminar discussions

More than any other philosophy course, this one helped me develop my critical thinking skills. The sheer amount of good modern philosophy papers - as opposed to what might be considered primary texts (yes, the distinction is a bit contrived, but I'm sure that any philosophy major reading this will know what I mean) - that you read in this course, coupled with the variegated approaches to philosophy writ large taken by each of these authors, is enough to guarantee this. The phenomenal lectures, which are always clear, incisive, and fair-minded, only add to this. There are many other specific skills you'll gain or develop: the two that come to mind at the moment are a passing facility with modal arguments (many many many parts of PoR rely on these forms of reasoning) and the ability to read Plantingese (the language Alvin Plantinga writes in.)
Survey of philosophy of religion, logical argumentation about various aspects of religiosity
I developed my foundational philosphical skills while also building a foundation of knowledge in religious philosophy.

my biggest takeaway from this course was learning how to put the logical doubts and questions I had about religion and theism into actual topics. Things like the problem of evil and religious pluralism stand out especially. Each topic of the course was great in that it provided a different angle to understanding philosophy of religion
Essay writing skills, reasoning skills, reading skills.
This class teaches you what you put into it. Doing all the readings will give you a good introduction to reading more difficult philosophy texts if you did not do DS.
The vocabulary to think about religion
I gained a general understanding of the philosophy of religion, and just as importantly I learned how to think more rigorously and precisely.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the lectures are engaging and thorough, readings are selected well, paper topics are awesome.

Weaknesses: in my view, the reading questions on the exam force memorization more than understanding.
great sections, good discussion, pretty good lecturing, great handouts

Strengths: really good survey course on Phil. of Religion. You hit all the major topics (problem of evil, divine knowledge, etc.) and Professor Pittard is a wonderful lecturer. 
Weaknesses: lowkey more work than you would expect. You do have to keep up with all the readings and juggle three exams and two papers. Finals season could be particularly brutal.

Strengths - section is fun
Weaknesses - online exams not fun since lots of people likely cheat and those who dont could be penalized by curve, tough to follow lecture sometimes, lecture notes a bit overwhelming

This is a fantastically-taught course which covers a wide gamut of topics, in a clearly organized fashion. It serves as a wonderful introduction to the topic, while the papers and sources discussed are themselves of high philosophical merit. Prof. Pittard is highly skilled at devising thought experiments and other arguments to really emphasize the weak points (or the main point) in a certain argument, and that is in itself a master class.
It is very apparent that there is simply too much to cover in too little time. I find that the course would be greatly improved if it were split into a two-course sequence, which would allow for a) not skipping any material and perhaps adding some important things, at the discretion of the professor, b) really opening up the floor to questions and facilitating discussion/debate in lecture (I know, I know, that that's what section is for, but section focuses mainly on the readings, while in lecture sometimes we introduce ideas and arguments, no hint of which is given in the readings [e.g. Boltzmann brains, axiarchialism, if I'm not mistaken]).
I think this course was structured extremely well for what it was, however, having 2 papers and 3 exams was a bit much.
I feel that the class is put together pretty well and does a good job of conveying the material.
It was great as an introduction to philosophy of religion, but it was unavoidable that it did not go very deep into specific topics.
Lecture could be more interesting/ engaging

Strength- a lot of reading, excellent handouts, good assignment structure
Weakness- a lot of reading! (I enjoyed having much interesting reading to think about, but struggled to keep up with the course pace)
The format of 'readings-first-and-lecture-later' was sometimes difficult to follow. If you didn't grasp the readings well, the lectures don't really help. Pace was alright.

Strengths: great prof, great TAs, very interesting content
Weaknesses: none!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Great foundation for anyone studying religion or philsophy. It also doesn't hurt if you miss a couple of lectures as the handouts are posted on line and are very thorough, and discussions sections can fill in any gaps.
Yes, if you're really interested in the course material, but not just for a humanities/phil credit.
yes, if you are particularly interested in the subject matter

Only if they have previous experience with metaphysics and are genuinely interested in arguments for, about, and against the supernatural. This is not a course for those who value practical applications of philosophy. The arguments are interesting, but highly abstract and it can be difficult to ascertain how these arguments are relevant to practical applications of philosophy. Lectures also tend to be highly abstract and they can be difficult to follow without some exposure to philosophical metaphysics.
Yes, if they enjoy philosophy.
Yes! But only if you're interested in the subject material.
This is a great first philosophy class and the material is such that anyone can feel a stake in it. Yes

This is an absolutely fantastic, eye opening course. Prof. Pittard is the goat and the TAs this year were both phenomenal. Pittard lectures are fire and his notes are a national treasure. It's an absolute metric ton of reading (and it's the philosophical kind), but your philosophical acumen will develop in proportion to the reading (it's mostly 20th century philosophical papers, which train your brain to think in a way that most philosophical primary texts don't.
I would! But be prepared to do most-all of the readings and really stay on top of things to do well in the course.
Yes, especially being a STEM kid I feel that this class was a new, interesting but challenging change.
Yes for sure. Regardless of one's spiritual beliefs, I feel that this course was important in firming up my own stance on the topic, something I feel everyone would benefit from
If it is interesting to you and you think you can keep up with readings then yes (about 30-40 pages a week but pretty dense Philosophy reading)
Absolutely! It was interesting and challenging.

Absolutely, I think the course is structured well, allowed for me to understand the major concepts of religion, and with a little improvement to the lectures, I think I would recommend the course to all students interested in religion.

I definitely would. This was one of my favorite courses I've taken at Yale. I'm not a philosophy major, but I took the course because I'm genuinely uncertain about the existence of God, and I wanted to understand what others have thought about this question throughout the ages and frame my thinking within this philosophical context. This course did exactly thatand also taught me the basics of epistemology and helped me think more rigorously and precisely. Do be aware that this class has a slightly higher workload than other classes, mostly because 1. the readings are very dense and 2. the class is structured in such a way that you kind of have to do the readings thoroughly to do well in the course. But honestly the workload made me get more out of the class, and the grading is pretty reasonable, so don't be scared away. This class is only taught once every few years, so if you have a chance I'd highly recommend that you take it while you can!
